content.value: Both Gatsby, the software, and the book
The Great Gatsby
share a common motif of magic.

In the book, there is an allusion to magic in the title, as the term "The Great" was often used before a magicians name, as in "The Great Houdini", who was famous during that time period. However, magic is more evoked in the plot, as the arc of the titular character Jay Gatsby plays out like a magic trick. Here is a quote from Christopher Nolan's movie
The Prestige
that describes the phases of a magic trick:

The first part is called the pledge, the magician shows you something ordinary. The second act is called the turn, the magician takes the ordinary something and makes it into something extraordinary... Now you're looking for the secret. But you won't find it because of course, you're not really looking... You want to be fooled.

Gatsby himself starts out as an ordinary man from the working class who falls in love with a wealthy woman named Daisy Fay. When he goes off to war, Buchan decides to marry a rich, though cruel, man named Tom Buchanan. Years later, Gatsby reappears, having completely transformed into the rich, classy man that he thinks Daisy would find suitable, and he's right. Daisy is stunned by the new Gatsby, and the two begin an affair.

Daisy, like most people in the city, is somewhat confused by the mysterious, party-throwing socialite that Gatsby had become, not knowing where exactly he'd been or how he'd made his money, but she doesn't ask too many questions. Like an audience at a magic show, she wants to be fooled.

The software, GatsbyJS, has a similar way of presenting itself. Jason Lengstorf, who helped write the software and teaches the Gatsby courses on FrontEndMasters.com has talked about the idea of "progressive disclosure of complexity" and abstractions, which, as he
puts it

: "allow someone to accomplish something while remaining blissfully unaware that any decisions were made at all". I understood this concept when I recently made a website for an app I was making and decided to try Gatsby out. Without really knowing what I was doing, I installed the program and saw that it basically just looked like a React app. I changed some colors and pictures around, add some text, and deployed it with Netlify. It took around 30 minutes.

When I pulled up the website though, I was a bit taken aback. The pictures did this interesting thing where they blurred in, and the website loaded incredibly quickly. Its speed performance was a perfect 100 on Google Lighthouse, for a site I had made without really thinking. I didn't know what Gatsby was doing, or what decisions they had made for me, but I didn't really care. It was magic.

The Great Gatsby ends with a jealous Tom revealing to Daisy that Gatsby made all of his money illegally, and their affair soon ends. The trick had been revealed, the slight of hand discovered, and the once mysterious Gatsby ends up dying alone in a swimming pool.
It's hard to say if my interest in the software will end up dissolving as quickly as Daisy's did with Gatsby. It was unveiled that they don't treat their employees well, which is
bad

and needs to be changed ASAP, and I'm not sure how sustainable it is that a simple website would contain so many files. It is also a private company, and at the end of the day there is no free lunch. Still, for the time being, I'd like to just enjoy the show.
